name: Water feature types
definition: The Water Foundation Theme depicts and specifies all surface water types and water resources including perpetual and transient water courses, artificial surface water bodies, and sea water. While it includes all water features that are intrinsic to (part of) a surface water hydrological network, it excludes ultimate uses of water such as irrigation and waterborne transport.

concepts.name: Hydro Node
concepts.definition: A node within the hydrographic network.

concepts.name: Watercourse Link
concepts.definition: A segment of a watercourse within a hydrographic network.

concepts.name: Watercourse Link Sequence
concepts.definition: A sequence of watercourse links representing a non-branching path through a hydrographic network.

concepts.name: Watercourse Separated Crossing
concepts.definition: An element in the hydrographic network used to indicate non-interacting crossing of watercourse links separated by level.

concepts.name: Abstract Hydro Feature
concepts.definition: This base abstract hydrographic class enables associations between different hydrographic feature instances representing the same real world entity. Three mechanisms are provided for this: a shared name attribute that allows an implicit association on the basis of a common name; a shared hydroID attribute where multiple representations are explicitly identified as the same instance; an explicit association between feature instances representing the same real-world entity.

concepts.name: Abstract Marine Layer
concepts.definition: A layer that may cover any part of a sea surface or sea bottom, represented as either a surface or point. The point representation reflects the reality that many Marine Layers are identified by point observations.

concepts.name: Coastline
concepts.definition: A special case of Shoreline at Lowest Astronomical Tide (LAT), the vertical datum reference used in the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia for viewing, discovery and general-purpose applications where a land/marine boundary is required. It is not designed to infer any political boundaries. The Coastline corresponds to the ‘nautical charting’ use case, whereas the Shoreline corresponds to ‘heighting’ and ‘cadastral’ use cases, with the vertical datum set accordingly to Mean Sea Level (MSL) and the Mean High Water Spring (MHWS) tides, respectively.

concepts.name: Inter Tidal Area
concepts.definition: The part of the marine environment that is exposed (not covered in water) during a normal tidal cycle; defined as the difference between any high and any low water level.

concepts.name: Marine Circulation Zone
concepts.definition: A sea area defined by its physical and chemical circulation patterns.

concepts.name: Marine Extent
concepts.definition: The extent of a sea area for a given tidal state.

concepts.name: Sea Area
concepts.definition: An area of sea defined according to its physical and chemical characteristics. It may have multiple geometries (extents) to represent different tidal states.

concepts.name: Sea Surface Area
concepts.definition: An area of the sea surface with some type of cover.

concepts.name: Seabed Area
concepts.definition: An area of the sea bed with some identified type of cover, for example, an area of vegetation or sediment type.

concepts.name: Shore Segment
concepts.definition: A section of shore line.

concepts.name: Shoreline
concepts.definition: A Boundary between a Sea Area and land. The Shoreline corresponds to ‘heighting’ and ‘cadastral’ use cases, with the vertical datum set accordingly to Mean Sea Level (MSL) and the Mean High Water Spring (MHWS) tides, respectively.

concepts.name: Abstract Hydro Point Of Interest
concepts.definition: A natural place where water appears, disappears or changes its flow.

concepts.name: Abstract Man Made Object
concepts.definition: A man-made object allowing the passage of water above or below an obstacle.

concepts.name: Abstract Surface Water
concepts.definition: Any known inland waterway body.

concepts.name: Dam
concepts.definition: A permanent barrier across a watercourse used to impound water or to control its flow.

concepts.name: Ditch
concepts.definition: A typically narrow artificial waterway created to contain water.

concepts.name: Drainage Basin
concepts.definition: Area having a common outlet for its surface runoff.

concepts.name: Embankment
concepts.definition: A man-made raised long mound of earth or other material.

concepts.name: Falls
concepts.definition: A vertically descending part of a watercourse where it falls from a height.

concepts.name: Fluvial Point
concepts.definition: A hydro point of interest that affects the flow of a watercourse.

concepts.name: Ford
concepts.definition: A shallow part of a watercourse used as a road crossing.

concepts.name: Land Water Boundary
concepts.definition: The line where a land mass is in contact with a body of water.

concepts.name: Lock
concepts.definition: An enclosure with a pair or series of gates used for raising or lowering vessels as they pass from one water level to another.

concepts.name: Rapids
concepts.definition: Portions of a stream with accelerated current where it descends rapidly but without a break in the slope of the bed sufficient to form a waterfall.

concepts.name: River Basin
concepts.definition: The area of land from which all surface run-off flows through a sequence of streams, rivers and, possibly, lakes into the sea at a single river mouth, estuary or delta.

concepts.name: Shore
concepts.definition: The narrow strip of land in immediate contact with any body of water including the area between high and low water lines.

concepts.name: Shoreline Construction
concepts.definition: An artificial structure attached to land bordering a body of water and fixed in position.

concepts.name: Sluice
concepts.definition: An open, inclined conduit fitted with a gate for regulating water flow.

concepts.name: Standing Water
concepts.definition: A body of water that is entirely surrounded by land.

concepts.name: Watercourse
concepts.definition: A natural or man-made flowing watercourse or stream.

concepts.name: Wetland
concepts.definition: A poorly drained or periodically flooded area where the soil is saturated with water, and vegetation is supported.
